content: @WG-async-sprint-planning just a reminder that our sprint planning meeting is tomorrow, 2021-11-11T09:00:00-08:00
@WG-async-sprint-planning time for our meeting!

Agenda, as always

  • Sprint retrospective
  • Assign [polish issues]
  • Identify sprint goals
Let's start by giving everyone 3 minutes or so to update the sprint doc
https://hackmd.io/gPgXC4fsTZOgOnd-Bwhoag?both
is the suffix of the doc deliberately commented out?
I am so confused by the doc :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
um
ugh
hackmd got out of sync, somehow
should be fixed now, I think
I needed to refresh
@nikomatsakis I'm not sure what progress got made on those other RFCs, did any get posted?
I posted the RPITIT RFC
sorry, lost track of time!
https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/3193
I gotta read the comments, there are a bunch
but mostly looks like clarifications, with the exception of @Gankra's comment :)
(which is too big for me to have parsed yet)
Sprint retrospective
I think we've mostly updated the doc now
How did the sprint go?
"very, very quickly"
It seems clear we got too ambitious again
(we = you + me, @tmandry)
yeah :) I was worried with the number of tasks under our initiative
maybe mostly me :)
also because our wednesday time got moved to after this meeting
yeah that didn't help
I'm seeing a lot of checked boxes under other initiatives, though :)
not so much under polish issues
I looked into mine some, but didn't make as much progress as I would want to
It's easy to deprioritize them as things come up :-|
I do have a pernos.co session uploaded for my polish issue. I’m debating whether it could make any sense to share it publicly, to let others browse it.
I wasn't sprinting, but I think I have just about caught up with the current work in progress
I think there was progress on most of the polish issues, just not quite enough to check the whole thing off.
I started looking into my issue enough to see that the error messages had changed
Maybe "fix <issue-number>" is a bit big for a single task and we should try to break them down further for each sprint.
I believe due to some of the work by @Jack Huey
I'd like to dig more
but I didn't get it done

eholk said:

Maybe "fix <issue-number>" is a bit big for a single task and we should try to break them down further for each sprint.

I was thinking this
let's try it..
@Yoshua Wuyts [he/they] and I made some progress on relanding InfoFuture, which wasn't planned but still counts as a polish issue.
I think the act of breaking down an issue into more concrete tasks is itself a task that can take a sprint, depending on the situation
Which error

pnkfelix said:

I do have a pernos.co session uploaded for my polish issue. I’m debating whether it could make any sense to share it publicly, to let others browse it.

I still want to about this rr thing the kids are talking about... so I might be interested in taking a look :-)
pernos.co is the :bomb:
I had a very simple example of async fns in traits MVP working but then we decided to go after implementing the RPITIT RFC first, so I've switched to that task

pnkfelix said:

I think the act of breaking down an issue into more concrete tasks is itself a task that can take a sprint, depending on the situation

mm yeah, I was thinking more of like "guess-timate a high-level goal"
honestly I think the biggest roadblock to using pernos.co and rr is that, for me, I do it on a rustc built with optimizations turned off and debuginfo-level=2
which means that sharing the pernos.co session with others can potentially have very high value
since it saves everyone else that build time for making that slow rustc
I wish optimizations could be turned on :/ but also it's not a boolean flag, something like -O1 would be reasonable I think?
(it might be a boolean in config.toml)
its a boolean in the config.toml, today at least. but you’re right, that’s a middle ground potentially worth looking into
I’ll put a link to the pernos.co session in the doc
ok
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
One thing I wanted to bring up: experimenting on a proc macro did wonders for prototyping speed, it's yet to be seen if it will help get contribs
nice!
Polish issues
I suspect most people are carrying theirs forward..
but here's the project board in case
I'm going to bulk-copy the ones from last sprint to the new one
okay, now we can go and make the goals more specific :)
So, for us.. I think our main goal should be to have the stakeholder meeting, @tmandry, and therefore to prepare the "user stories" we talked about
I'd like to start that today/tomorrow and put in a bunch of time on monday
probably the named types RFC will just wait
I think I agree with that, but those aren't polish issues ;)
oh, sorry
nah it's fine, we don't have to be ultra strict about it
I am wondering actually
I just want to make sure we're covering everything
I had put off further progress on my first polish issue because @oli was going to work on intersection regions
but afaik he hasn't had time for that
I may pick that back up
@oli are you around?
I think I could actually finish off that issue, and come back to #71723
that is, I had that fix for #63033, I don't think I want to land that PR, but I think I do know the PR I want to land :)
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
I'm going to put "either or" for now
(basing end-topic on doc activity, no need to rush if you aren't ready)
ok
Identify sprint goals

nikomatsakis said:

So, for us.. I think our main goal should be to have the stakeholder meeting, tmandry, and therefore to prepare the "user stories" we talked about

I don't quite remember the details of the user stories we were talking about. Is this like the shiny future narratives?
yeah
I wanted to basically pick 2 or 3 scenarios
and write out how we saw each one working
I have some in mind
I even started this but got distracted

my goal: Add more docs and clean up https://rust-lang.github.io/wg-async-foundations/vision/roadmap/scopes.html and the sub-pages below it. As mentioned before scoped spawn is v interesting to me, but I think clarifying the options here will be super helpful, as well as show what the actual blockers are
@triagebot end-topic I'm going to leave this here for when people are done updating the doc

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
also
I'm realizing that the next sprint meeting will be on Thanksgiving
and I'm going to be out all week
I realize this doesn't affect everyone here, but it probably affects a lot of us..
yeah we should cancel it
Yeah, I'll be out then too
4 week sprint!
but given that thanksgiving occurs
we can sprint so far!
more like 2 weeks in reality :)
or we could shift everything back a week..
and BREAK THE PATTERN?!
yeah, we could :)
LOL
back in which direction?
either is prob ok for me, I don't think I have things scheduled on the "alternating" weeks :)
4 weeks seems like an eternity for now, how will I ever get the motivation to do things :)
@pnkfelix in the future direction
I’ve got a lot going on, I think 4 weeks sounds fine
we could also use the triage meetings to help people plan in the event they get all their tasks done
I'm fine with whatever people want :)
okay, sounds like there's more of a preference for 4 weeks
I personally prefer to just keep the cycle, come hell or high water (and cancel rather than move)
calendars are hard enough as is
wow, I'll be able to make so much progress on my polish issue knocks on wood
Step 1: Get rr working on your dev box
I added some goals to the portability section, its basically just "get started"

pnkfelix said:

Step 1: Get rr working on your dev box

That's one sprint gone :big_smile:
If anyone is interested in the portability stuff and would like to schedule a chat to discuss, please let me know

Nick Cameron said:

I added some goals to the portability section, its basically just "get started"

yay! I'm really happy this is happening :-)
I have thoughts and opinions but I think they're mostly reflected in the existing documents
@Nick Cameron you may be interested in this issue template for kicking off new initiatives
I might be interested in chatting about portability, though I need to refresh that part of my brain a bit
no rush :-)

..okay I'm going to do a new one of these because of the backscroll

@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
(next I will paste the tasks and we can have questions/feedback)

Async fundamentals

  • [ ] Stakeholder meeting
    * [ ] Schedule stakeholder meeting
    * [ ] Prepare notes / slides for stakeholder meeting
    * [ ] Have stakeholder meeting
  • [ ] Get MVP RFC merged
  • [ ] Implement RPITIT RFC
  • [ ] Post RFC for function types with nameable output type
  • [ ] Write-up a plan for "dyn type adaptation procedural macro" along the lines of this post and try to recruit someone to implement
This still feels like a lot, I guess, but it is a long sprint

Polish

Goals:

  • [ ] Create a list of confusing error message issues for the error messages goal
  • [ ] Update must not suspend lint page to reflect current status

Issues:

  • [ ] Better output when .awaiting on sync fn #66731 (estebank)
  • [ ] [#89734] Unhelpful compiler message when a reference is used inside of an await block #723120 (estebank)
  • [ ] (nikomatsakis) Async function leads to a "more general type" error #71723
    - or maybe pick "Async fn does not compile if lifetime does not appear in bounds (sometimes)" #63033 back up again
  • [ ] (tmandry) E0623 highlights wrong parameter in async fn #74256
    - [ ] Find the root cause
    - [ ] Get a fix mostly working locally
    - [ ] Put up an initial PR
    - [ ] Draft PR for follow-up fixes (or roll them into the same one)
  • [ ] (eholk) Dropped variables still included in generator type #57478 (part of #69663)
    - [ ] Finish fixpoint iteration
    - [ ] Figure out how to handle AssignOp with new backing data structures
    - [ ] Make existing test suite pass
    - [ ] Post PR for review

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) Strange async use ...; compiler suggestion #87613
    - pernos.co link
    - [ ] identify why generated span of item covers fn main, and not async fn main

  • [ ] (guswynn) warn on must_use use on async fn's #89610

  • [ ] (guswynn) must_not_suspend was made unstable, which causes problems that may need and MCP to fix: https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/469
I'm basically continuing with my theme of "define/refine the goals we have" for polish
about desugaring for MVP RFC and subitems, let's remove it from the list, that's deferred and let's add stuff for RPITIT
I can do that, should I do it directly on sprint doc I guess?
wow look at all of those granular, achievable goals

Santiago Pastorino said:

I can do that, should I do it directly on sprint doc I guess?

yes, please!

Portability across runtimes

  • [ ] (nrc) create process boilerplate (issues, repo, etc)
  • [ ] (nrc) continue research on the current state of the ecosystem
  • [ ] (nrc) blog post on background
  • [ ] (nrc; stretch) blog post on the project - goals, call to action, etc.
the boilerplate might take up more than you expect :) though I hope it's not unnecessarily so
(I also made the issue template so we could keep track of things that aren't quite done, maybe we should revisit those soon)

Tooling

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) revisit original non-responsiveness issue to see if it was resolved
  • [ ] (pnkfelix) talk to eliza about make tracking issue for issues that are blocking a non-preview release
  • [ ] (pnkfelix) update roadmap to point to https://github.com/rust-lang/async-crashdump-debugging-initiative

Gus Wynn said:

my goal: Add more docs and clean up https://rust-lang.github.io/wg-async-foundations/vision/roadmap/scopes.html and the sub-pages below it. As mentioned before scoped spawn is v interesting to me, but I think clarifying the options here will be super helpful, as well as show what the actual blockers are

ah i need to add this to the doc huh

Async iteration

Goals:

  • [ ] Clean up proc macro to not need sigils for disambiguation
  • [ ] Experiment with the alternative modes of operation for ?
  • [ ] Experiment with different ways of setting size_hint that require less code than the current approach
  • [ ] Add rustc_generator attribute to annotate fns as a placeholder to uplift logic from proc-macro
  • [ ] Stretch goal: Add ItemKind::Generator or a new field on functions in type system, with no new syntax
  • [ ] Stretch goal: start experimenting with for await pat in expr in proc-macro

Gus Wynn said:

Gus Wynn said:

my goal: Add more docs and clean up https://rust-lang.github.io/wg-async-foundations/vision/roadmap/scopes.html and the sub-pages below it. As mentioned before scoped spawn is v interesting to me, but I think clarifying the options here will be super helpful, as well as show what the actual blockers are

ah i need to add this to the doc huh

I would categorize this as "General" since it's not part of an initiative currently, btw
but I'm glad you're cleaning up those docs, always appreciated!

ok, I think we can
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
I will say that seeing all of this progress has me really excited!

that's the last topic so
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
Okay, thanks everyone!!
Next sprint meeting is in 4 weeks, see you then
